In poker hands, each hand has requirement of specific number of cards: e.g., Straight Flush: 5 cards same suit consecutive. Four of a Kind: 4 cards same rank. Full House: 5 cards with 3+2. Flush: 5 same suit. Straight: 5 consecutive. Three of a Kind: 3 same rank. Two Pair: 4 cards with two pairs. Pair: 2 same rank. High Card: 1 card.

We can also play a subset of any size? The rules state: "When deciding which cards from this list to play" and "All the played cards must form part of a poker hand, or equivalently, the set of played cards must not contain cards that will not form part of the poker hand." That suggests we must play a set of cards that corresponds exactly to one of the defined poker hands. So we cannot play e.g., 3 cards that are not a hand. So we must choose a subset that exactly matches a valid hand.

We can choose any of the defined poker hands as long as the cards used match that hand. We can also choose a different hand with fewer cards e.g., Pair (2 cards). We cannot play 6 cards.

Goal: maximize final score.

We need to compute score for each possible hand we can form from the given cards.

We can use 5 cards for many hands, 4 for four of a kind, 3 for three of a kind, 4 for two pair, 2 for pair, 1 for high card.

Full house? Need 3 and 2 of same ranks. Not possible.

Flush? Need 5 cards same suit. We have clubs: 10♣x, 2♣+. That's 2 clubs. Spades: J♠x, 9♠x, 3♠ – 3 spades. Hearts: 8♥x – 1. Diamonds: 7♦, A♦+ – 2. None have 5. So can't play flush.
